Come, O haste thee, beauteous Spring!</br>To deck, once more, the teeming earth;</br>Come, O haste, and with thee bring,</br>Gentle Love, and smiling Mirth.
The melting frosts bedew the way,</br>Where-e'er thy flow'ry footsteps tread;</br>The morning-breezes round thee play,</br>Perfumes the fluttering zephyrs spread.
Ye gentle maids, your welcome guest,</br>The Spring, with solemn rites, receive;</br>At whose arrival, every breast,</br>With soft desires, begins to heave.
She comes!  behold, o'er yonder hill</br>The rising verdure marks her way;</br>Now let the pipe exert its skill,</br>And virgin-voices chant the lay.
By thee the trees with leaves are dress'd;</br>By thee the rivers freely flow;</br>To thee, their patroness confess'd,</br>The rural gods their pleasures owe.
Our flocks, within the wintry fold</br>Scarce shelter'd from the beating rains,</br>At thy approach, forget the cold,</br>New vigour dancing in their veins.
At thy approach, the joyful steer</br>Ranges the meeds with wanton pride;</br>Or feeds secure, regarding near</br>The fav'rite heifer at his side.
By thee, from yon bleak mountain's head</br>Torrents descend of melted snow;</br>Impatient, the new waters lead</br>Their winding path to vales below.
There, first, the stream abates its force;</br>And, wand'ring thro' th' enamel'd mead,</br>Glides slowly, with unwilling course,</br>As loth to leave so sweet a bed.
For thee, adorn the smiling field</br>Wide-waving seas of rising corn,</br>Which, to th' industrious farmer yield</br>The promise of a rich return;
Who now remembers, with delight</br>How dear this pleasant prospect cost;</br>The painful day, the sleepless night,</br>The autumn-sun, the winter-frost.
By thee we view the swelling down</br>New robes of vary'd verdure wear;</br>By thee the mingled flow'rs are blown,</br>That beautify the infant year.
See how to charm the eye, the smell,</br>With various odours, various dyes,</br>The primrose, violet, daffadil,</br>In the rich pomp of nature, rise.
With these, by some clear fountain's side,</br>To native charms, the blooming maid</br>Shall join the arts of rural pride,</br>Adorn the bosom, deck the head.
While, lurking close behind the spray,</br>Th' enamour'd swain, unheeded pries;</br>Thy heart, fond youth, shall dearly pay,</br>The forfeit of thy curious eyes.
The silken line, and bearded hook,</br>The wily angler now prepares;</br>Now, to unpeople every brook,</br>The long neglected mash repairs:
Now, o'er the harmless finny race,</br>He spread the wide-destroying net;</br>Or now, with treacherous art, he lays</br>Death hid beneath the tempting bait.
In thee, sweet season, o'er the grass,</br>The wanton lambkins bound and play;</br>In thee, the shepherd and his lass</br>Fondly sport the livelong day.
The warbling birds, at early morn,</br>Proclaim thy welcome, beauteous Spring;</br>And grateful joy, in thy return,</br>By thee they love, to thee they sing.
But, see, the westward sun descends,</br>And scarcely leaves a doubtful day;</br>See, from the pastures, Thirsis bends,</br>He, and his counted flock, their way.
'Tis twilight now, and, ere 'tis long,</br>The night will spread its thickest gloom;</br>Here let us end our humble song,</br>Or else repeat the rest at home.</br>
